prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person in the WIBTA (Would I Be Terrible for...) scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves an adult stepdaughter living with her mother's partner, and he wants to kick her out.

First, I need to consider the legal aspects. Since the stepdaughter is 19 and an adult, the person writing can't legally force her out unless she's a tenant. If she's living there without a lease or formal agreement, maybe she's considered a lodger. But if she's a tenant, the author might need to follow proper eviction procedures. But the question is about being in the wrong morally, not legally.

The author mentions that the stepdaughter has been indifferent and unappreciative. They tried to build a relationship but gave up after she didn't acknowledge him buying her a car. Now, the author wants her to leave because they want privacy with their fiancée. The fiancée is okay with it, but might be upset.

Is it wrong? Well, the author is the one who set up this situation by staying in a relationship with the mother, which led the daughter to stay. The author also supported the daughter financially by buying her a car. Now, expecting the daughter to leave might be a bit harsh, especially if she's saving money. The author's reasoning is that it's time for her to move out on her own, which is a common expectation. However, the author is using their own space and relationship needs as justification, which could be seen as selfish. But maybe it's reasonable to expect an adult child to leave once they have the means.

On the other hand, the author hasn't done anything to help her move out, like offering support or setting boundaries earlier. They just waited for her to leave. So, maybe the author is in the right because it's an adult's choice to stay, but if they're not contributing or helping, the author has the right to ask them to leave. However, the way the author is approaching it (not caring about her reaction) might come off as harsh.

But the key point is that the stepdaughter is an adult and responsible for her own decisions. The author isn't her parent anymore in terms of legal guardianship. So, the author's actions might be justified if they're not legally obligated to support her. The author is just asking an adult child to move out, which is a normal part of life. So, the answer might be B (No), the author isn't in the wrong. However, some might argue that the author should have addressed this issue earlier or that the stepdaughter has a right to stay if she's contributing. But since she's not contributing and the author is the one providing the house, the author's stance is understandable.
